The number of applied grants is based on numbers of mobilities carried out during the school year 2016 -2017 and on the plans done for next project year.

Project '2-DARE'   (D & A  Reach out to Europe - Two) builds on the success of the first year of the mobilities programme under the VET Charter (year 1 is still in progress)  

To recap, the  original principles which drove the international strategy are that the Charter would facilitate the internationalising of the curriculum, where all academic areas would have the opportunity to devise programmes that include a mobility, aligned to their course requirements, and cross college support services, who previously might not have considered a mobility, would become equally involved. 

Possessing the Charter means that the College staff can think long term and plan their mobilities to fit with their academic and term timeframes.  The request for information and enquiries about mobilities is now at an all-time high, from across all areas of the curriculum.

We have run an ongoing internal communications campaign to publicise and promote the Erasmus Mobilities which uses all forms of media – from leaflets, to broadcasts on the portal, to running roadshows, a presentation to all academic areas, and the publication of a complete Mobility Handbook.  The campaign has been nominated for a College Development Network Marketing award - the winner to be announced on March 9th.

Project 2-DARE therefore involves reviewing the current year’s programme, involving departments in reviewing their experience and turning the strategy into a series of yearly objectives as per the application.  Awareness after the campaign is now much higher – requests have come in for meetings with administration, MIS, reception staff and janitors!  A range of new and existing partner providers and organisations have been selected and new sections of the College are now engaged which will inspire new teaching and development approaches.  These mobilities should evolve into long term partnerships working on projects which will be of mutual benefit for years to come.

The feedback from all groups participating this year has been uniformly high: Some quotes from participants:

“The experience was completely life changing and career affirming. It helped me personally and professionally and everyone should have the chance to experience something as positive as this experience was for me!” - Jade Anderson, HND Performing Arts student, France 2016 

“This was an incredibly worthwhile exchange with very professional partners with whom we have already planned further exchanges of knowledge.”  – Christine Calder, OD staff, Finland 2016

This has led to an an increased demand from across the college, which is very encouraging. 

The first year’s experience had highlighted the fact that on some mobilities an extra accompanying person is very useful, either to help with logistics (eg driving) or on the educational and social programme and to further develop the relationship between institutions. 

All staff and students receive a pre-mobilty ’programme’ – following the processes detailed in the D&A Handbook,  whereby language training needs, and any other special needs are assessed, and country familiarisation briefings take place. There will be discussions concerning the schedule and programme, and staff will also relate to their opposite number to identify issues in advance. Staff will receive briefings on assessment and support issues, inc. ECVET, and travel arrangements will be handled by the administration section of the International team as well as an external travel company. The Mobility + tool will be used to record the mobilities and other information that is created, as Project 2-DARE progresses. Common issues will be identified and cross college learning will be fed back into the planning for succeeding mobilities.

This course was selected because it fits in well with our School's European development plan. Being able to send a teacher to Spain for linguistic and cultural training is a fantastic opportunity to ensure that our staff are trained to the best possible level they can be.  Harris Academy aims to offer a wide variety of languages and levels.

We have applied to the European Commission for funding for a three week language immersion course in Malaga, Spain. The course will allow the participant, Kathleen Murray to engage in linguistic training to help her gain confidence and proficiency in Spanish as well as cultural activities and excursions to deepen participants' understanding of Spain and its culture. 

The course is an immersion course and therefore participants will be expected to only converse in Spanish for the weeks that they are participating in the course. The course is run specifically for language teachers and it will focus on how to teach Spanish to young  people. In addition, the course will enable all participants to share resources and ideas for teaching Spanish.  We believe that Kathleen will return with more confidence in Spanish, helping her with ideas, methodologies and resources to teach young people.

Kathleen already teaches French and Spanish at Harris Academy, but lacks the residency requirements set out by the GTCS. The funding received from Erasmus will allow Kathleen to teach two languages to Advanced Higher level. This will in turn benefit the school greatly, in allowing Harris Academy to offer and teach a wide variety of language courses to all young people at all levels.

It is hoped that Harris Academy will benefit greatly from Kathleen attending this immersion course as we will be able to offer more language courses for young people who attend Harris Academy. In addition this will help to raise the schools European profile and we are confident that this project will enable us to create links with other European schools, whilst helping to broaden the horizons of young people at Harris Academy.

Bollnäs municipality has been working actively for many years with policies to reduce unemployment and build up skills for groups which are far away from the labor market. It could be long-term unemployed young people, new arrivals and so forth.
The work, which consists of various adapted policies and educational sections, is successful, among other things depending on a targeted management and an active and committed staff.
The content of the programs offered to participants is extensive and includes: mapping, coaching, guidance, job creation and vocational learning/training at workplaces. Our staff works directly with the above tasks and we see Erasmus + as a great tool for developing staff skills.
The aim of our project is that staff should be able to get to know different ways of working with vocational education, to be able to compare and to draw conclusions from different working methods and to expand their skills. The point of doing this with the help of Erasmus + is that they can simultaneously develop intercultural skills and linguistic skills.
A total of 20 people will be offered the opportunity to participate in the project. There are persons who work with the vocational education and management staff. In addition to vocational education, we are interested in different ways of management and managing learning activities.
Each participant visits his/her "job shadow site" for five business days. In place, they will follow a colleague in his/her daily work.
Participants will go to one of the countries Germany, Wales, Scotland or Spain. They always go at least two people to the same place. In addition to participating actively during the week in the other country, they should be prepared to present themselves and AME in Bollnäs, their daily work etc. as well as after the completed visit, share experiences with colleagues and other stakeholders.
Through the project, the participant gains extended competence and new inspiration in his/her work, the organization develops its international work and continues to build an international network. At the same time, the municipality/region gets inspiration for similar forms of competence development.
Mobility as a Catalyst for Apprentice Success

Adjuvant Limited, since it's incorporation in May 2009, has been involved in the delivery and financial management of EU Vocational Education and Scottish Government projects with the cumulative project values exceeding £7 Million. 

This application for VET learner mobility on behalf of apprentices employed as professional players at seven Scottish football clubs (our sending partners). Mobility will comprise 156 mobility VET learners, the majority being apprentices, and 33 accompanying persons who will travel to  Spain, Portugal and Turkey. This may seem like large mobility project but the experience of our staff in European mobility is unparalleled with over 50 years of collective experience in Leonardo da Vinci and Erasmus+ project management and delivery. 

Evidence from previous mobility projects has shown that success rates for Scottish mobility participants in being offered a professional contract can be dramatically increased through participation in European mobility, with a 2-3 fold increase in the likelihood of apprentices becoming professional footballers. 

Another value-added benefit of mobility participation is the finding that apprentices who are unsuccessful in being offered a professional contract are significantly more likely to be offered employment in a secondary career pathway than those who have not undertaken mobility. Unemployment among mobility participants is less than 4%, compared to 45% unemployment in peers from other Scottish clubs who have not undertaken mobility. The consequential improvement in informal learning, soft skills, cultural awareness and linguistic abilities as a result of mobility has proven to be a major deciding factor for employers. 

This mobility project will enhance the employability of Scottish apprentices and allow them to experience the culture, language and training methods at an acknowledged (UEFA) Centre of Excellence, which is applauded as having world class record in talent identification, innovative coaching and player development.  

The project objectives are:
1. Improved tactical, technical, physical and mental competences for participants as a direct result of mobility.
2. Improved employment rates for mobility participants either as a professional footballer or in alternative career pathways.
3. Accreditation and validation of mobility informal learning and soft skills.
4. Improved linguistic skills for participants and an awareness of the cultural diversity within Europe.
5. A commitment to embed mobility principles within the Modern Apprenticeship Programme.
6. Increased maturity and self-esteem among participants.
7. Dissemination of practices, policies, systems and project outcomes at the employer, local regional and national levels in the UK and in Europe.
8. Incorporation of the project outcomes and best practice within the work and social environments of the project partners.
9. Increase understanding of interconnections between formal and non-formal education.


This mobility project will directly strengthen the links between the Scottish Sending partners, European host partners and vocational training providers Scotland through exchange of information at the institutional level and will facilitate the the introduction of innovations in coaching technology to Scottish club academies. Dissemination activities will accelerate the process of mainstreaming the skills and technology transfer from Europe into Scottish vocational education programmes.
Patways for upskilling students in Europe

The project responds to the need that VET schools have to provide their students with the chance to increase and improve the quality of vocational training, by taking internships in European companies, and getting in contact with the single European labour market.

The success of the collaboration in the previous consortium integrated by 9 Public VET schools of the Valencian Region and promoted by the IES Ramón Esteve, the high rate of insertion of the students to the labor market (90%), the great interest and the satisfaction of the students and the coordinators who participated in the previous project, as well as the close and fluid collaboration of the VET schools involved in the consortium, have fostered the present project that it will satisfy the demands of the VET schools makes possible the collaboration with enterprises at national  and European level. The dissemination actions of the results have made possible the incorporation of 2 VET schools more.

The project integrated by 11 VET schools in Valencian Region is adressed to 77 VET students and former students who are doing the 2nd year of the cycles of intermediate level in informatics and communications, agrarian and administration; or graduates in the last year: medium-level technicians from these specialties. The project foresees 8 monthly flows (4 to Italy, 1 to Portugal, 1 to Brussels, 1 to Latvia and 3 to UK) and 2 Erasmus Pro flows of three months (1 to Italy and 1 to UK) Each VET schoolwill select 2 former students and 5 students, one of them Erasmus Pro. There are 5 flows to Italy and 3 to the UK because the profile of the partners as well as the different geographical areas of them will enable the students to carry out their work. training in different fields since companies, even if they are from the same sectors, are very different.

The main OBJECTIVE of the project is:
To allow VET students to develop, through training practices in European companies, the skills and abilities to complete, in a practical way, the skills acquired in VET to be incorporated efficiently into the  European labor market, either on account own or for others. To do this, VET students needs to develop specific tecnical skills on the specialty that they has studied, but transversal, social and intercultural skills will also be necessary to face new challenges and become active citizens with values for the future.

The main ACTIVITIES  will be carried out are:
- PREPARATION of the motilities: selection of the participants, initial evaluation of their competences, pre-departure training of participants, logistics and agreements’ tasks definition, coordination, etc.
- IMPLEMENTATION OF THE MOBILITY. Implementing the internship programs in the companies. The mobility also includes cultural activities.
- EVALUATION OF THE PARTICIPANTS. The competences that will be acquired during the stay abroad will be evaluated according to the ECVET system and will be previously set, during the initial evaluation. All the internship activities will be planned to achieve these competences and will be customized.
- MONITORING. The development of the internships will be monitored by all the tools and processes, previously agreed by the project.
- EVALUATION OF THE PROJECT. 
- DISSEMINATION. The dissemination activities will be carried out in all project’s phases. A final conference for the dissemination of the project’s results will be organized. Besides the impact on the participants, the project will benefit all partners, fostering the European cooperation and relationships between companies and educational centres.

The DISSEMINATION activities and the mobility itself will generate an IMPACT at local, regional and national level. 

The IMPACT of the project will be:
The project will improve the opportunities for VET students to be actively incorporate national or European labor market, either on their own account or as an employee, in a more effective way
The collaboration between the participating organizations will allow promoting European cooperation and internationalization and it will make it possible to bring companies closer to VET schools and it will improve too the collaboration with other VET schools, public authotities, etc. It will give participating entities a vision about most demanded professional profiles and the skills that students must learn

The project is directly linked to the 2020 strategy, the skills agenda and the European priorities  to help the EU and its Member States generate a higher level of employment, productivity ,social cohesion and development.
Dundee Football Club in the Community Trust (SCIO)

Dees without Frontiers is a collaboration between Dundee Football Club Trust and Fundación Córdoba Club de Fútbol that brings together 40 young people aged 13-16  from the most disadvantaged communities in Scotland and Spain. 2 groups of participants will undertake youth mobility projects 

The project aims to-

Reach marginalised young people, challenge insular mindset, limited life experience & chances due to lack of equity as a result of their background (incl. economic, social, family, religious & ethnic), educational attainment, gender, health, etc. (EU2020 & E+)
Remove them from the comfort zone of their daily lives and to introduce them to the experience of travel; to gain cultural awareness, interact and work with a group of peers from Cordoba, Spain of a similar age range & backgrounds (better social cohesion & active citizenship) (ET2020 & E+)
Work as a group to a timetable of activities, workshops & discussion, to learn, appreciate & practice the values of tolerance, empathy, open-mindedness, civic responsibility & democracy, particularly across geographic, language, cultural and religious frontiers, and to embrace and find synergy in diversity (better social cohesion & active citizenship (ET2020 & E+)
Teach healthy living, diet, exercise & mindset and instil attitudes that will stay with them (positive impact on poverty & social exclusion (EU2020 & E+)
Instil core values of teamwork, initiative, problem solving, fair play and competitiveness, accepting rules and dealing with conflict. In terms of communication, confidence and expression, active listening, better digital awareness and ability to adapt and apply media and digital skills to learning and personal development (video blogs etc) (addressing common skills shortages on workforce (ET2020) & better employment rates, (EU2020 & E+)
Challenge ability to communicate with peers of a different language, develop  basic Spanish language skills,
Disseminate the impact of their experience amongst peers, families, communities (positive impact on poverty & social exclusion (EU2020 & E+)
Raise aspirations towards education and the workplace (less early school leaving) (EU2020), embracing lifelong learning and future mobility (EU2020 &E+)

Phase 2 brings participants together to research, logistically plan, goal set, fund raise and budget within a group environment to support further activity within mobility. Phase 2 includes language classes, a growth mindset workshop, team building day and a finance workshop to support future learning and direction for these individuals. 

Phase 3  will see both Scottish and Spanish participants pair together in Cordoba for 6 days to complete football training tasks to develop teamwork, communication, understanding and social skills. Language sessions developing English and Spanish for both groups will be used to build knowledge and skills to communicate with our partnering groups during activity and with locals when visiting landmarks and planning activity. Time will also be spent delivering session focusing on health and well being, these are arranged to educate participants on the qualities of foods, how to manage food intake and how to establish a balanced diet. Reflection periods have also been placed within mobility where participants can continually review their personal development and match their achievements up against agreed /shared learning outcomes at the start. In addition to this reflection period all participants will be asked to plan a small number of activities during mobility which incorporate both groups in landmark visits, research opportunities and team building activity. 

Post mobility - Will see participants evaluate their experiences over the past 6 months through a report. An independent review through Dundee City Council will also take place during project time. This allows participants, DFC staff and partnering organisations to see what changes they have undergone in their mindset, skills, aspirations and attitudes. We will gather as a group for the final stage, and invite speakers to talk about what employers' expectations are, recruitment plans, etc, further education institutions talk about possible college options, individuals from training organisations who have expertise in working with young people and who can offer them further opportunities e.g. volunteering (including volunteering abroad). Each participant will develop and agree their own Action Plan, and even for those who are continuing or re-engaging with school, we will ensure they are offered extra-curricular activities and contact is maintained. We will undertake 3,6 and 12 month follow ups and at the end of the project in 2019, we will host a celebratory event including all participants, partner organisations and parents.

Long-term aims of this project are to encourage greater social inclusion for the group with DFC looking to support the inspired levels of development which shapes the brighter future.
Dundee Football Club in the Community Trust (SCIO)

The most essential way of implementing Omnia's international Strategy is to plan and carry out reciprocal student and expert mobilities from and to Omnia. Part of the internalization strategy objectives are also carried out in Erasmus + KA2- development projects, in which Omnia is developing for instance new pedagogigal practises and high-quality education for immigrant students.
During the present project period Omnia's partner network has expanded with a few target areas: Lithuania, Croatia, Portugal, Malta and Mallorca. Our aim is to start reciprocal student mobility co-operation with our new Lithuanian partner in the field of property maintenance, because Omnia has educated this field already for years, but there has not been international co-operationin this field in the past years at all in Omnia. We also aim to send some students in the next project period to Portugal, because during this project period only staff members have visited from Omnia there. We send mostly students from the fields of business and administration, audiovisual communication and technical fields to Malta and Mallorca.

In the becoming project period Omnia's co-operation partners' network would be expanded with ten new partners, which are located partially both in new target countries and partially in excisting partner countries. Omnia is for instance starting co-operation in metal field with a new German partner college, security field co-operation with a new Danish college and  going on IT-field co-operation with a new Irish language school after this spring's piloting mobilities there. We also sent first students to Malta and Mallorca via our new partner institutions this year and are looking forward to hear students' experiences in these new areas.


We are exclunding Hungary from our present partner countries in this project, because in two years no student or staff member has applied there. Omnia's biggest partners will continue co-operating with Omnia: they are European multi-field co-operation colleges, with whom we make reciprocal co-operation. Omnian has most of its partner organisations and colleges in Germany. In this application there are ten German institutes. Co-operation with them is well-working and flexible and Omnia's students and experts  consider the country interesting. That is the reason for a big number of applied grants to Germany in this application. We apply also grants for two ten-student-groups to Germany and this fact adds also the number of applied mobilities to Germany.

Omnia is also co-operating to some scale directly with smaller European companies. Some vocational fields (social and health care) have most of their partners without PIC. We will add these partners during the project period in the Mobility Tool-platform. 

In this application Omnia applies also 8 grants for long;  5-6 months mobilites for audiovisual communication, tourism, hotel and restaurant field and business and administration fields students. Omnia took part in piloting long mobilities in a project called European Pathway, a Gateway to work and got very good experiences of them. There were no difficulties of recruiting students for these mobilities and we believe that also in future there would be suitable applicants for them.
